definitions: take blood from a person or animal for medical testing or donation
give a young hunting hound its first experience of tracking prey
examples: The nurse will blood you before your surgery tomorrow
The veterinarian blooded several cattle to test for disease
They blooded the young foxhounds during Saturday's hunt
The trainer blooded the new dogs with an easy trail

definitions: cause blood to flow from someone or something through injury
cover or mark something with blood leaving visible stains
examples: The boxer bloodied his opponent's nose with a powerful punch
She bloodied her knees when she fell on the gravel
The hunter bloodied his hands while dressing the deer
The accident bloodied the pavement for several yards

definitions: produce flowers or be in the state of producing flowers
grow or develop in a healthy or vigorous way especially in one's prime
become covered with a powdery or waxy coating on the surface
examples: The roses bloom beautifully in early summer each year
Cherry trees bloom for only two weeks in spring
Her artistic talent bloomed during her college years
The business bloomed under the new management team
The chocolate bloomed after being stored in warm conditions
The grapes bloomed with a natural protective coating

definitions: produce flowers especially on a fruit tree before fruiting
mature or develop in a promising or healthy way reaching full potential
examples: The apple trees blossom earlier than usual this year
Orange trees blossom with fragrant white flowers in spring
She blossomed into a confident young woman at university
Their friendship blossomed over shared interests and values

definitions: make a spot or stain especially with ink on paper or fabric
dry wet ink or liquid by pressing absorbent material against it
hide or obscure something from view by covering or blocking it
examples: She accidentally blotted the letter with her fountain pen
The child blotted his homework with spilled juice
Blot the excess oil from the pizza with paper towels
She blotted her lipstick carefully with a tissue
Dark clouds blotted out the sun completely yesterday afternoon
The new building will blot the view from our window

definitions: mark or become marked with irregular patches or spots of color
examples: The disease blotched the leaves with brown and yellow spots
Crying had blotched her face with red patches
His skin blotched badly after the allergic reaction occurred
The old painting was blotched with water damage stains

definitions: expel air forcefully from the mouth or produce a current of air
be moved or carried by the wind or air current
produce a sound by forcing air through an instrument or device
explode burst or break suddenly from internal pressure or force
miss waste or fail to take advantage of an opportunity or chance
examples: She blew on her hot coffee to cool it down
The whale blew water high into the air above
The leaves blew across the yard in the autumn wind
Her hair blew wildly in the strong ocean breeze
He blew the trumpet loudly at the football game
The referee blew his whistle to stop the play
The tire blew suddenly on the highway causing an accident
The electrical fuse blew during the thunderstorm last night
He really blew his chance at the job interview
They blew a twenty point lead in the fourth quarter

definitions: cry noisily and uncontrollably with heaving sobs and gasping breath
examples: The child blubbered for hours after losing her favorite toy
He blubbered uncontrollably when he heard the tragic news
She was blubbering so hard she couldn't speak clearly
The actor blubbered convincingly during the emotional scene

definitions: create a detailed plan or technical drawing for construction or manufacturing
examples: The architect blueprinted the entire building before construction began
They blueprinted the new software system over several months
The team carefully blueprinted their strategy for market expansion
Engineers blueprinted the bridge design using advanced computer software

definitions: try to deceive someone by pretending to have strength knowledge or intention you lack
mislead opponents in a card game by betting heavily on a weak hand
examples: She bluffed her way into the exclusive party without invitation
He bluffed about his qualifications during the job interview
The poker player bluffed with only a pair of twos
She successfully bluffed her opponents into folding better hands

definitions: make a serious mistake due to ignorance carelessness or stupidity
move clumsily or uncertainly bumping into things or stumbling
examples: The CEO blundered badly by announcing layoffs before Christmas
She blundered when she revealed the surprise party plans
He blundered through the dark room knocking over furniture
The drunk man blundered into several tables leaving the bar

definitions: make an edge or point less sharp by wearing down or damage
speak in a direct manner without trying to be polite or kind
examples: Cutting metal will blunt the scissors very quickly over time
Years of use had blunted the knife blade considerably
She blunted her criticism with a few kind words first
He always blunts his opinions regardless of people's feelings

definitions: make or become unclear or less distinct to see visually
become vague indistinct or difficult to perceive or remember clearly
make the difference between things less clear or definite
examples: Tears blurred her vision as she read the letter
The photographer deliberately blurred the background for artistic effect
The details of that day have blurred in my memory
Everything blurred together after the third glass of wine
Modern technology has blurred the line between work and home
The new policy blurs the distinction between employees and contractors

definitions: develop a red color in the face from embarrassment shame or modesty
feel embarrassed or ashamed about something that has happened or been said
examples: She blushed deeply when he complimented her beautiful dress
The teenager blushed whenever anyone mentioned his girlfriend
He blushed to admit he had never read Shakespeare before
I blush when I remember my behavior at the party

definitions: get on or into a ship aircraft train or other vehicle
provide regular meals and accommodation for payment or live somewhere as a lodger
cover or seal something with pieces of wood or boarding material
examples: Passengers may board the plane through gate twelve now
We boarded the cruise ship at Miami port yesterday
She boards students in her large Victorian house downtown
He boarded with a local family during his studies
They boarded up the windows before the hurricane arrived
The old shop was boarded over years ago already

definitions: talk with excessive pride about one's achievements possessions or abilities
possess or have something to be proud of as a notable feature
examples: He constantly boasts about his expensive car and house
She boasted that she had never missed a day's work
The city boasts three museums and five art galleries
The hotel boasts spectacular views of the mountain range

definitions: travel somewhere in a boat especially for pleasure or recreation
transport someone or something in a boat across water
examples: We boated along the river all afternoon enjoying nature
They boat to the island every weekend during summer
The rescue team boated supplies to the flood victims
Fishermen boated their catch back to the harbor

definitions: move quickly up and down or back and forth repeatedly
cut hair in a short style that is all one length
examples: The cork bobbed on the surface of the water
She bobbed her head in agreement during the meeting
The hairdresser bobbed her hair in a trendy style
She decided to bob her hair for the summer

definitions: move with an irregular bouncing or rocking motion unsteadily
fumble or handle something clumsily especially dropping or mishandling
examples: The ball bobbled across the uneven field surface slowly
His head bobbled as he dozed in the chair
The quarterback bobbled the snap and lost crucial yards
She bobbled the hot dish and nearly dropped it

definitions: ride or race in a bobsled down an ice track at high speed
examples: They bobsledded down the Olympic track at incredible speeds
She learned to bobsled during her winter vacation in Switzerland
The team bobsleds competitively in international championships every year
He bobsledded professionally for ten years before retiring

definitions: be a sign or omen of a particular outcome usually good or bad
examples: Dark clouds bode ill for our outdoor wedding plans
These early results bode well for the project's success
The economic indicators bode poorly for next quarter's growth
Her confident smile boded success in the upcoming interview

definitions: give material form to something abstract or represent in bodily form
examples: The sculpture bodies forth the artist's vision of freedom
These policies body the principles we have always supported
The actor bodied the character with remarkable physical presence
Ancient Greeks bodied their gods in human form

definitions: cause to sink or become stuck in wet muddy ground
prevent from making progress or slow down with difficulties or complications
examples: The truck bogged in the muddy field after rain
Our car bogged down in the swampy ground
Don't bog the discussion with unnecessary details please
The project bogged down in bureaucratic red tape

definitions: score one stroke over par on a golf hole during play
examples: He bogeyed the difficult seventh hole despite good positioning
She rarely bogeys when playing her home course
The champion bogeyed three holes in the final round
I bogeyed the last hole and lost the match

definitions: heat liquid until it reaches the temperature where it bubbles and turns to vapor
cook food by immersing it in boiling water or liquid
be filled with intense anger or other strong emotion
examples: Water boils at one hundred degrees Celsius at sea level
She boiled the kettle to make tea for everyone
Boil the pasta for ten minutes until tender
My grandmother boils vegetables until they're completely soft
He was boiling with rage after the unfair decision
The crowd boiled with excitement as the team scored

definitions: print or display text in thick heavy type for emphasis
examples: The editor boldfaced all the important terms in the textbook
Please boldface the headings to make them stand out
She boldfaced key points in her presentation slides
The designer boldfaced the company name on the brochure

definitions: support strengthen or reinforce something that is failing or weak
examples: The new evidence bolstered the prosecution's case significantly
Government spending bolstered the economy during the recession
She bolstered her argument with extensive research and data
Extra pillows bolstered his injured back while sleeping

definitions: run away suddenly or escape typically from fear or danger
fasten something securely with a bolt or metal pin
eat food very quickly without proper chewing usually from hunger
examples: The horse bolted when it heard the loud noise
She bolted from the room in tears
He bolted the door securely before going to bed
Workers bolted the steel beams together for safety
The children bolted their lunch to get back outside
Don't bolt your food or you'll get indigestion

definitions: attack destroy or damage something using bombs or explosives
fail completely especially in a performance or attempt
examples: Enemy planes bombed the city throughout the night
Terrorists bombed the embassy causing massive damage
The comedian bombed terribly at the corporate event
The new movie bombed at the box office

definitions: attack a place or person continuously with bombs or other projectiles
subject someone to a continuous flow of questions information or criticisms
examples: Artillery bombarded the fortress for three days straight
Enemy forces bombarded our positions throughout the night
Reporters bombarded the celebrity with personal questions
The company bombarded customers with promotional emails

definitions: form an emotional connection or relationship with someone
join or fasten things together securely especially with adhesive
examples: The mother bonded instantly with her newborn baby
The team bonded during their weekend retreat together
This glue bonds metal to plastic very effectively
The layers bond together when heated under pressure

definitions: remove the bones from meat or fish before cooking or eating
examples: The chef carefully boned the chicken before stuffing it
She boned the fish fillets for the children
Can you bone this salmon for me please
He boned the leg of lamb with expert precision

definitions: make a deep resonant sound like a large bell
examples: The church bell bonged twelve times at midnight
Big Ben bongs every hour on the hour
The gong bonged loudly to signal dinner time
The clock bonged mysteriously in the empty house

definitions: shout boo to show disapproval or contempt especially at a performance
examples: The audience booed the referee after the controversial call
Angry fans booed the team off the field
They booed loudly when the villain appeared on stage
The crowd booed and hissed at the politician's speech

definitions: dance energetically to rock or pop music especially at a party
examples: They boogied all night at the disco club
Everyone was boogieing to the live band's music
She loves to boogie whenever her favorite songs play
The wedding guests boogied until the early morning

definitions: reserve accommodation a ticket or service in advance of use
officially record the name and offense of someone being charged by police
examples: She booked a table at the restaurant for eight
I need to book my flight to Paris soon
The police booked him for drunk driving last night
They booked three suspects in connection with the robbery

definitions: make a loud deep resonant sound like thunder or explosion
experience rapid growth increase or success especially in business
say something in a loud deep voice that carries
examples: Thunder boomed across the valley during the storm
The cannon boomed at noon every day
Business is booming since we opened the online store
The tech industry boomed in the late nineties
The sergeant boomed orders at the new recruits
His voice boomed across the crowded auditorium

definitions: return to the originator often with negative consequences or unexpected results
examples: His harsh criticism boomeranged when people defended her
The smear campaign boomeranged and damaged their own reputation
Their cost cutting measures boomeranged causing quality problems
The plan to embarrass him boomeranged spectacularly

definitions: increase improve or help something to be more successful or effective
help someone climb or reach something by lifting or pushing them up
examples: The new advertising campaign boosted sales by thirty percent
Regular exercise will boost your energy levels significantly
Can you boost me up to reach the high shelf
He boosted his daughter onto his shoulders

definitions: kick something or someone hard with the foot
start up a computer system loading the operating system
forcibly remove or dismiss someone from a place or position
examples: He booted the ball high over the fence
The player was penalized for booting an opponent
Boot your computer and check for system updates
The system failed to boot after the power outage
Security booted the troublemakers from the nightclub
They booted him from the team for missing practice

definitions: make produce or distribute illegal goods especially alcohol or recordings
sell or distribute products without proper authorization or licensing
examples: They bootlegged whiskey during the prohibition era
Someone bootlegged the concert and sold copies online
Street vendors bootleg designer handbags in the city
He was arrested for bootlegging copyrighted movies

definitions: build up or achieve something from minimal resources through one's own effort
examples: She bootstrapped her company from her garage to success
They bootstrapped the entire project without external funding
He bootstrapped himself from poverty to wealth through hard work
The startup bootstrapped for two years before seeking investment

definitions: drink alcohol especially in large quantities or habitually
examples: He boozed heavily every weekend with his friends
They boozed all night at the bachelor party
She's been boozing too much since losing her job
College students often booze at fraternity parties

definitions: hit or strike someone or something lightly with the hand
dance or move rhythmically to pop or jazz music
examples: She playfully bopped him on the nose with her finger
The child bopped the balloon back and forth
They were bopping to the music at the club
Everyone bopped along to the catchy tune

definitions: form the boundary or edge of an area or surface
be next to or share a boundary with another place
come very close to or be almost the same as something
examples: Trees border the property on all four sides
A white fence borders the garden beautifully
France borders Spain along the Pyrenees mountain range
Our yard borders the Johnson's property
His behavior borders on obsession with that hobby
The story borders on the unbelievable

definitions: make a hole in something using a drill or other tool
make someone feel weary and uninterested by being dull or tedious
examples: Workers bored through solid rock to build the tunnel
He bored a hole in the wall for the cable
His long speeches bore everyone at the meetings
Don't bore the audience with too many statistics

definitions: take and use something belonging to someone else with intention to return it
take or adopt an idea word or method from another source
examples: Can I borrow your car for the weekend trip
She borrowed twenty dollars from her sister yesterday
English borrows many words from other languages extensively
The artist borrowed techniques from the impressionist movement

definitions: disturb interrupt or annoy someone causing mild irritation or inconvenience
take the trouble or make the effort to do something
feel worried anxious or concerned about something
examples: Please don't bother me while I'm trying to concentrate
The loud music really bothers the neighbors at night
Don't bother cooking tonight we'll order takeout instead
Why bother arguing when you know you're wrong
What's bothering you today you seem really upset
It bothers me that he never apologized

definitions: put liquid into bottles for storage distribution or sale
keep emotions or feelings hidden inside rather than expressing them
examples: The brewery bottles thousands of beers every day
We bottle our own olive oil from the harvest
She bottles up her anger instead of expressing it
Don't bottle your feelings talk to someone

definitions: cause a narrowing or congestion that slows movement or progress
examples: Construction bottlenecks traffic every morning on this highway
Too many approvals bottleneck the decision making process
The narrow bridge bottlenecks the flow during rush hour
Outdated software bottlenecks our entire production system
